body: Now, it is possible to be immune to inbreeding depression. Okay, let us imagine that a population had done inbreeding for a long period of time. It is inevitable that the recessive alleles would be expressed as equivalent to that of the dominant alleles. This is where the harsh natural selection would be putting upon the now expressed recessive alleles. Okay, for a thousand years from now on. They still do inbreeding and assume that they survive from purifying selection or negative selection (it means natural selection that wipes out deleterious alleles). All of the deleterious alleles have been removed from the population. Meanwhile, recessive alleles that are advantageous to evolutionary fitness would survive and be spread throughout the population. Inbreeding is necessary for the expression of advantageous recessive phenotypes.

Now, what inbreeding does is that it makes more of the recessive alleles would get more expressed. This is why you get the infamous Habsburg inbreeding because there are all of those unexpressed recessive alleles now being more expressed with each successive generation of inbreeding. However, if a population had done inbreeding for a long time to the point that recessive alleles are equally as expressed to that of the dominant alleles. This means that natural selection would be putting more selective pressures against those recessive alleles.  It should be noted that not all recessive alleles are deleterious. It's just that in comparison, deleterious alleles would be more present within recessives rather than dominant ones. To state that all deleterious alleles are recessive is just misunderstanding the whole thing.

Continuing from below, because it seems that there's a character limit. The reason why the deleterious recessive alleles would survive more than the deleterious dominant alleles is that they aren't being expressed. This is the exact reason why recessive alleles would have much more deleterious alleles. After all, they don't get expressed as much as that of the dominant alleles. As such, they don't get wiped out by harsh Darwinian selection, they face pretty much less selective pressure. Meanwhile, deleterious dominant alleles would get easily wiped out by Darwinian selection because they are being more expressed.

Reading some of the comments, I would set straight about Incest babies. Let us take dominant alleles and recessive alleles.  Dominant alleles that are evolutionary fit would be then spread throughout the population. Meanwhile, dominant alleles that aren't evolutionary fit would be then wiped out due to harsh Darwinian selection. They would get eradicated. Now imagine, a dominant allele that would make you allergic to water. Well, you aren't evolutionarily fit at all and your genes aren't gonna spread to the whole population. Now, imagine that the allele for water allergy instead of it being dominant is rather recessive. If you hold that recessive allele of water allergy instead of the dominant allele of water allergy. You would survive, you could reproduce with someone else. The gene could spread out to the population. Alleles that don't do any evolutionary fitness and instead reduce it are called deleterious alleles.
